title: What are trees made of?

multiple-choice.question: Where do trees primarily get their mass from?
What experiment did Johann Baptist Van Helmholt conduct to determine where the mass of a tree comes from?

options.label: A
options.text: He measured the amount of sunlight a tree received over five years.

options.label: B
options.text: He carefully measured the amount of soil in a pot, planted a tree, and took care of it for five years.

options.label: C
options.text: He watered a tree with a measured amount of water over five years.

options.label: D
options.text: He observed the growth of a tree in a controlled environment.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Johann Baptist Van Helmholt's experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The mass of the soil increased by 72 kilograms.

options.label: B
options.text: The mass of the tree increased by 72 kilograms, while the mass of the soil decreased by 60 grams.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass of the tree decreased by 60 grams, while the mass of the soil increased by 72 kilograms.

options.label: D
options.text: The mass of the tree and soil remained the same.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The person and the tree would remain the same size.

options.label: D
options.text: The person and the tree would both get bigger.

title: The physics of playing guitar - Oscar Fernando Perez

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you pluck a guitar string?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a vibration that translates through the neck and bridge to the guitar's body.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a vibration that only affects the surrounding air molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a standing wave that only moves at the nodes.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a vibration that only affects the guitar's body.

multiple-choice.question: What determines the pitch of a sound produced by a guitar string?
What are the four factors that affect the frequency of a vibrating string?
What is the fundamental wave in a guitar string?

options.label: A
options.text: The wave that determines the pitch of the note

options.label: B
options.text: The wave that determines the volume of the note

options.label: C
options.text: The wave that determines the tone of the note

options.label: D
options.text: The wave that determines the rhythm of the note

multiple-choice.question: What are overtones in a guitar string?

options.label: A
options.text: Waves that have frequencies that are multiples of the fundamental wave

options.label: B
options.text: Waves that have frequencies that are lower than the fundamental wave

options.label: C
options.text: Waves that have frequencies that are higher than the fundamental wave

options.label: D
options.text: Waves that have frequencies that are unrelated to the fundamental wave

multiple-choice.question: How does the way you pluck a guitar string affect the sound produced?

options.label: C
options.text: It affects both the fundamental wave and the overtones

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the sound produced

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis of the Western scale?

options.label: A
options.text: The overtone series of a vibrating string

options.label: B
options.text: The fundamental wave of a vibrating string

options.label: C
options.text: The frequency of a vibrating string

options.label: D
options.text: The amplitude of a vibrating string

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the frequency of two notes that are an octave apart?

options.label: A
options.text: The frequency of the higher note is twice the frequency of the lower note

options.label: B
options.text: The frequency of the higher note is half the frequency of the lower note

options.label: C
options.text: The frequency of the higher note is three times the frequency of the lower note

options.label: D
options.text: The frequency of the higher note is four times the frequency of the lower note

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of frets on a guitar?

options.label: A
options.text: To divide the string's length by 2^(1/12) to produce half steps

options.label: B
options.text: To divide the string's length by 2 to produce octaves

options.label: C
options.text: To divide the string's length by 3 to produce thirds

options.label: D
options.text: To divide the string's length by 4 to produce fourths

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of playing two notes whose frequencies are close together?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces a sound wave with a constant amplitude

options.label: B
options.text: It produces a sound wave with a rising and falling amplitude

options.label: C
options.text: It produces a sound wave with a constant frequency

options.label: D
options.text: It produces a sound wave with a changing frequency

options.text: A story with multiple, unrelated meanings

options.label: C
options.text: A story that is an extended metaphor, symbolizing real-life events

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: George Orwell was his stage name as an actor

multiple-choice.question: What motivated George Orwell to write Animal Farm?

options.text: To promote the ideals of the Russian Revolution

options.label: B
options.text: To criticize the effects of totalitarianism on ordinary people

options.label: C
options.text: To write a children's story about farm animals

options.label: D
options.text: To explore the themes of romance and love

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: A

multiple-choice.question: What was George Orwell's intention when he tried to get arrested?

options.label: B
options.text: To experience prison life and write about it

options.label: D

title: The Greek Crisis Explained in Under 3 Minutes

title: Who am I? A philosophical inquiry - Amy Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What is the central question that has puzzled philosophers, psychologists, academics, scientists, artists, theologians, and politicians throughout history?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the meaning of life?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the nature of reality?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the purpose of existence?

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that refers to the idea that our identity remains the same despite changes over time?
Which Greek historian used the story of a ship to demonstrate the complexity of the persistence of identity?
What is the name of the mythical founder King of Athens who single-handedly slayed the evil Minotaur at Crete?
What is the paradoxical question that arises from the story of the Ship of Theseus?

options.label: A
options.text: Does the ship remain the same if all its parts are replaced?

options.label: B
options.text: Is the ship still the same if it is repaired?

options.label: C
options.text: Can a ship be rebuilt from its original parts?

options.label: D
options.text: Is the ship's identity tied to its physical parts?

multiple-choice.question: What is the argument that some people make regarding the Ship of Theseus, stating that despite changes, it remains the same ship?

options.label: A
options.text: The ship's identity is tied to its physical parts.

options.label: B
options.text: The ship's identity is tied to its qualitative properties.

options.label: C
options.text: The ship's identity remains the same due to gradual changes.

options.label: D
options.text: The ship's identity is not affected by changes over time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the twist that complicates the paradox of the Ship of Theseus?

options.label: A
options.text: The ship is rebuilt from its original parts.

options.label: B
options.text: The ship is repaired with new parts.

options.label: C
options.text: The ship is sailed by a different person.

options.label: D
options.text: The ship is docked in a different location.

multiple-choice.question: How does the paradox of the Ship of Theseus relate to human identity?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans are like ships, with constantly changing parts.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans have a fixed identity that does not change.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans are defined by their physical bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are defined by their thoughts and feelings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge of answering the question "Who am I?"

options.label: A
options.text: It requires a simple and straightforward answer.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires a deep understanding of philosophical paradoxes.

options.label: C
options.text: It requires a knowledge of psychology and sociology.

options.label: D
options.text: It requires a spiritual or religious perspective.

multiple-choice.question: What is the humorous suggestion made at the end of the transcript for answering the question "Who am I?"

options.label: A
options.text: To consult a philosopher or psychologist.

options.label: B
options.text: To reflect on one's thoughts and feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: To answer "I am a legendary hero sailing a powerful ship on an epic journey."

options.label: D
options.text: To say "I don't know" and give up.

title: How does a jellyfish sting? - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of a jellyfish's body is made up of water?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture prey and protect the jellyfish

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the jellyfish's body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To aid in the jellyfish's digestion

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the largest species of jellyfish, which has tentacles that can extend over 100 feet?
How do nematocysts, the whip-like hollow tubules, eject venom from the jellyfish's stinging cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a mechanical or chemical trigger that opens the lid of the cell

options.label: B
options.text: Through a process of osmosis that releases the venom

options.label: C
options.text: Through a muscular contraction that forces the venom out

options.label: D
options.text: Through a chemical reaction that breaks down the venom

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended treatment for removing lingering tentacles stuck to the skin after a jellyfish sting?

options.label: C
options.text: Applying heat to the affected area

options.label: D
options.text: Using a topical cream to neutralize the venom

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not recommended to use fresh water to rinse off jellyfish stingers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can activate the nematocysts and cause further stinging

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can dilute the venom and make it less effective

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can cause an allergic reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can push the stingers further into the skin

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the jellyfish species that releases venom that can cause contraction of the heart muscles and rapid death in large doses?
What adaptation do leatherback turtles have that allows them to eat jellyfish without getting stung?

options.label: A
options.text: A specialized digestive system that breaks down the venom

options.label: B
options.text: A thick layer of skin that protects them from the stingers

options.label: C
options.text: Backwards-pointing spines in their mouth and esophagus

options.label: D
options.text: A powerful beak that can crush the jellyfish's stingers

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way nudibranchs, or sea slugs, defend themselves against predators?

options.label: B
options.text: They steal the jellyfish's defenses by eating the cnidocytes

options.label: C
options.text: They have a specialized shell that protects them

options.label: D
options.text: They can release a cloud of ink to confuse predators

multiple-choice.question: What potential medical application are scientists exploring using jellyfish stingers?

options.label: A
options.text: Delivering medicine through the use of nematocysts

options.label: B
options.text: Developing a new type of pain reliever

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a vaccine against jellyfish stings

title: The benefits of good posture - Murat Dalkilinç

multiple-choice.question: Why is good posture important?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps you look more confident and attractive.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the foundation for every movement your body makes and determines how well your body adapts to stresses.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only important for athletes and individuals who engage in physical activity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important for overall health and well-being.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to muscles when posture is not optimal?

options.label: A
options.text: They become stronger and more flexible.

options.label: B
options.text: They become tight and inflexible, while others are inhibited.

options.label: D
options.text: They become weaker, but more flexible.

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential consequences of poor posture?

options.label: A
options.text: Scoliosis, tension headaches, and back pain.

multiple-choice.question: How can using computers or mobile devices affect posture?

options.label: A
options.text: They encourage good posture by promoting upright sitting and standing.

options.label: B
options.text: They have no impact on posture.

options.label: C
options.text: They encourage looking downward, which can promote poor posture.

multiple-choice.question: What should the spine look like when viewed from the front or back?

options.label: B
options.text: It should be shaped like an "S".

options.label: C
options.text: All 33 vertebrae should appear stacked in a straight line.

options.label: D
options.text: It should be curved like a "C".

multiple-choice.question: How can you determine if your posture is good when standing up?

options.label: A
options.text: You should be able to draw a straight line from your head to your heels.

options.label: B
options.text: You should be able to draw a straight line from a point just in front of your shoulders, to behind your hip, to the front of your knee, to a few inches in front of your ankle.

options.label: C
options.text: Your knees should be bent at a 90-degree angle.

multiple-choice.question: What is important for maintaining good posture while sitting?

options.label: A
options.text: Keeping your neck tilted forward and your shoulders tense.

options.label: B
options.text: Keeping your neck vertical, shoulders relaxed, and knees at a right angle.

options.label: D
options.text: Leaning forward and putting your elbows on your knees.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not enough to just have good posture?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not important for overall health and well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: Because keeping your muscles and joints moving is also extremely important.

options.label: C
options.text: Because good posture is only important for athletes and individuals who engage in physical activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not necessary to exercise or move regularly.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if you are stationary for long periods with good posture?

options.label: A
options.text: You will experience improved balance and coordination.

options.label: B
options.text: You will experience reduced muscle strain and fatigue.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be worse than regular movement with bad posture.

options.label: D
options.text: You will experience improved digestion and immune function.

multiple-choice.question: Who can help you if you are concerned about your posture?

options.label: C
options.text: A personal trainer or fitness coach.

title: Solid, liquid, gas and … plasma? - Michael Murillo

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the universe is made up of plasma?
What happens to the water molecules in steam when it is heated to a high enough temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: They combine to form a solid.

options.label: B
options.text: They separate into freely roaming hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the ionization process in a gas?

options.label: C
options.text: The negatively charged electrons escape the atoms, leaving behind positively charged ions.

multiple-choice.question: How do plasmas behave in an electric field or magnetic field?

options.label: A
options.text: They behave the same as particles in other types of matter.

options.label: B
options.text: They are accelerated by electric fields and steered in circular orbits by magnetic fields.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not affected by electric or magnetic fields.

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear in electric or magnetic fields.

multiple-choice.question: What is generated when particles within plasma collide or are accelerated by electricity or magnetism?
What is an example of a practical application of plasma technology?
How do plasma chemists use plasmas in healthcare?

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy or alter targeted chemicals, killing pathogenic organisms.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future use of plasma technology?

options.label: B
options.text: To permanently rid landfills of their waste

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease air and water quality

multiple-choice.question: What is another potential future use of plasma technology?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove toxins from our air and water

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using plasma technology in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: A limited supply of renewable clean energy

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in greenhouse gas emissions

options.label: D
options.text: A potentially unlimited supply of renewable clean energy

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Inside the minds of animals - Bryan B Rasmussen

multiple-choice.question: What was Aristotle's view on the difference between humans and animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans possess reason, while animals can only follow brute instincts for survival and reproduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans are driven by instincts, while animals possess reason.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans and animals are equal in terms of intelligence and reason.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are superior to animals due to their physical strength.

multiple-choice.question: Who suggested that animals following instincts are indistinguishable from robots responding mechanically to stimuli in their environments?
What was Darwin's hypothesis regarding intelligence in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Intelligence is unique to humans and cannot be found in animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence can evolve from simpler instincts.

options.label: C
options.text: Animals are born with intelligence, while humans acquire it through learning.

options.label: D
options.text: Intelligence is not a characteristic of animals or humans.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of an animal solving a complex problem?

options.label: A
options.text: A dog barking at a stranger.

options.label: B
options.text: An elephant using an object to reach an inaccessible place.

options.label: C
options.text: A cat sleeping in the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: A bird flying south for the winter.

multiple-choice.question: What do behaviorists, such as Pavlov and Thorndike, argue about animals that appear to think?

options.label: A
options.text: They are usually only responding to reward or punishment.

options.label: B
options.text: They are using complex problem-solving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: They are communicating with each other using a special language.

options.label: D
options.text: They are demonstrating consciousness and self-awareness.

multiple-choice.question: What was the case with Clever Hans, a horse with the amazing ability to tap out answers to math problems?

options.label: A
options.text: He was especially good at math.

options.label: B
options.text: He was reading his unwitting trainer's subtle nonverbal cues for when to stop tapping.

options.label: C
options.text: He was using a complex problem-solving strategy.

options.label: D
options.text: He was demonstrating consciousness and self-awareness.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of an animal demonstrating complex social behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: A dog playing fetch with its owner.

options.label: C
options.text: Elephants recognizing each other after years apart and mourning their dead.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Hard Problem" in the philosophy of mind?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding how animals solve complex problems.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding what it is like to be a non-human animal.

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding how humans think and behave.

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the difference between humans and animals.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to know for sure whether other people have consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we can't directly observe their thoughts and feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they might be pretending to be conscious.

options.label: C
options.text: Because consciousness is a unique human trait.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we can't communicate with them effectively.

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of animal minds testing the limits of our understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: It reveals more about animal minds than human minds.

options.label: B
options.text: It reveals more about human minds than animal minds.

options.label: C
options.text: It reveals that animals are superior to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: It reveals that humans are superior to animals.

title: Jean-Paul Sartre and Existentialism

multiple-choice.question: Where was Jean-Paul Sartre born?

options.label: A
options.text: Living without taking freedom properly on board and shutting our eyes to other options

options.label: B
options.text: Living with a specific person or making our home in a given place

options.label: C
options.text: Doing a particular kind of work or having a certain career

options.label: D
options.text: Believing in the existence of God

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "absurdity of the world" in Sartre's philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that life has a preordained logic and is inherently meaningful

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that things are weirder than we think and the world reveals itself as far stranger and more uncanny than we normally admit

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that humans are not free and are bound by their circumstances

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that existence is not fluid and we cannot create new institutions, habits, outlooks, and ideas

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He is neutral about capitalism and its effects on society

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Who did Sartre visit and admire deeply?

options.label: A
options.text: We will come up against the "angoisse" or "anguish" of existence

options.label: B
options.text: We will be bound by our circumstances and unable to make choices

options.label: C
options.text: We will be forced to live in "bad faith"

options.label: D
options.text: We will be relieved of all responsibilities and obligations

multiple-choice.question: What is Sartre's view on human existence?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes it is predetermined and has a preordained logic

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks it is fluid and we can create new institutions, habits, outlooks, and ideas

options.label: C
options.text: He is neutral about human existence and its nature

options.label: D
options.text: He believes it is absurd and has no inherent meaning

multiple-choice.question: Why did the FBI keep a large file on Sartre?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because of his views on capitalism and its effects on society

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Kant's Axe

multiple-choice.question: What is Immanuel Kant's stance on telling a lie to a would-be murderer who asks for the location of your best friend?

options.label: A
options.text: It is morally acceptable to tell a lie to save your friend's life.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not morally acceptable to tell a lie, even if it means putting your friend's life at risk.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the circumstances and the potential consequences of telling the truth or lying.

options.label: D
options.text: Kant did not address this specific scenario in his philosophy.

multiple-choice.question: What is a "categorical imperative" according to Immanuel Kant?

options.label: A
options.text: A moral principle that applies only in certain situations.

options.label: B
options.text: A moral principle that applies to everyone, regardless of the consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: A moral principle that is based on personal opinions and feelings.

options.label: D
options.text: A moral principle that is determined by the majority.

multiple-choice.question: How does Immanuel Kant's moral stance differ from utilitarianism?

options.label: A
options.text: Kant believes that the consequences of an action determine its morality, while utilitarianism does not.

options.label: B
options.text: Kant believes that some actions are inherently wrong, regardless of their consequences, while utilitarianism prioritizes the greatest happiness.

options.label: C
options.text: Kant and utilitarianism share the same moral principles, but differ in their application.

options.label: D
options.text: Kant rejects the idea of moral principles, while utilitarianism emphasizes their importance.

multiple-choice.question: What is a deontological approach to ethics, as exemplified by Immanuel Kant?

options.label: A
options.text: An approach that prioritizes the consequences of an action in determining its morality.

options.label: B
options.text: An approach that emphasizes the importance of personal opinions and feelings in moral decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: An approach that focuses on the inherent rightness or wrongness of an action, regardless of its consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: An approach that rejects the idea of moral principles and instead emphasizes individual freedom.

multiple-choice.question: According to Immanuel Kant, what would be the consequence of telling a lie to the would-be murderer, even if it led to the desired outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: The lie would be justified, and the outcome would be morally acceptable.

options.label: B
options.text: The lie would be on your conscience, and you would be partially responsible for any consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: The lie would have no moral implications, as the outcome would be the only consideration.

options.label: D
options.text: The lie would be irrelevant, as the outcome would be determined by chance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between Immanuel Kant's moral philosophy and utilitarianism?

options.label: A
options.text: Kant prioritizes the greatest happiness, while utilitarianism emphasizes the importance of moral principles.

options.label: B
options.text: Kant emphasizes the importance of moral principles, while utilitarianism prioritizes the greatest happiness.

options.label: C
options.text: Kant and utilitarianism share the same moral principles, but differ in their application.

options.label: D
options.text: Kant rejects the idea of moral principles, while utilitarianism emphasizes their importance.

multiple-choice.question: According to Immanuel Kant, what is the moral imperative in the scenario with the would-be murderer?

options.label: A
options.text: To tell a lie to save your friend's life.

options.label: B
options.text: To tell the truth, regardless of the consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: To prioritize your own safety and well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: To consider the potential consequences of telling the truth or lying.

multiple-choice.question: How does Immanuel Kant's moral philosophy address the idea of personal responsibility?

options.label: A
options.text: Kant believes that individuals are not responsible for the consequences of their actions.

options.label: B
options.text: Kant believes that individuals are partially responsible for the consequences of their actions, even if they are unintended.

options.label: C
options.text: Kant believes that individuals are only responsible for the intended consequences of their actions.

options.label: D
options.text: Kant does not address the idea of personal responsibility in his philosophy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "axe man" example in Immanuel Kant's moral philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: It illustrates the importance of considering the consequences of an action in determining its morality.

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the difference between Kant's moral philosophy and utilitarianism.

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrates the importance of telling the truth, regardless of the consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that Kant's moral philosophy is based on personal opinions and feelings.

multiple-choice.question: According to Immanuel Kant, what is the relationship between moral principles and consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: Moral principles are determined by the consequences of an action.

options.label: B
options.text: Moral principles are independent of the consequences of an action.

options.label: C
options.text: Moral principles are based on personal opinions and feelings, rather than consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: Moral principles are irrelevant in determining the morality of an action.

title: How do pregnancy tests work? - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the earliest known method of testing for pregnancy, dating back to 1350 BC in Ancient Egypt?

options.label: A
options.text: Urinating on wheat and barley seeds to see if they sprout.

options.label: B
options.text: Using a small device to detect HCG in urine.

options.label: C
options.text: Observing changes in the body, such as a missed period.

options.label: D
options.text: Drinking a special potion to induce a reaction.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Ancient Egyptian method, what was believed to determine the sex of the baby?

options.label: A
options.text: The speed at which the wheat seeds sprouted.

options.label: B
options.text: The speed at which the barley seeds sprouted.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of HCG in the urine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the hormone that modern pregnancy tests are designed to detect?
What is the role of HCG in early pregnancy?

options.label: B
options.text: To support the formation of the placenta.

multiple-choice.question: How do over-the-counter pregnancy tests work?

options.label: A
options.text: By detecting changes in body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: By detecting HCG in urine using antibodies and enzymes.

options.label: C
options.text: By observing changes in cervical mucus.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a special device to detect fetal heartbeats.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the control zone on a pregnancy test?

options.label: A
options.text: To confirm that the test is working properly.

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the presence of HCG.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the sex of the baby.

multiple-choice.question: What can cause false negatives on a pregnancy test?

options.label: D
options.text: Taking the test too late in the day.

multiple-choice.question: What can cause false positives on a pregnancy test?

options.label: C
options.text: Certain cancers, such as uterine or testicular cancer.

multiple-choice.question: Why do doctors recommend taking a pregnancy test first thing in the morning?

options.label: A
options.text: Because HCG levels are highest in the morning.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the test is more accurate in the morning.

options.label: C
options.text: Because beverages can dilute the urine sample.

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way for a woman to confirm a pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking a home pregnancy test.

options.label: B
options.text: By visiting a doctor's office for a more sensitive and quantitative test.

options.label: C
options.text: By observing changes in her body.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a special device to detect fetal heartbeats.

options.label: C
